name: Articles
definition: Articles are words (a, an, the) that define a noun as specific or unspecific. They are determiners that come before nouns.
importance: Articles help clarify whether we're talking about something specific or general. Mastering articles is crucial for natural English communication.
tagline: A, An, The ‚Äì Small words, BIG impact!

types.name: Definite Article (The)
types.description: Used when referring to specific or particular nouns that both speaker and listener know about.
types.rule: Use 'the' when the noun is specific or unique. Both speaker and listener know which one.

types.name: Indefinite Article (A)
types.description: Used before singular countable nouns that begin with a consonant sound. Refers to any member of a group.
types.rule: Use 'a' before consonant SOUNDS (not just consonant letters). Listen to pronunciation.

types.name: Indefinite Article (An)
types.description: Used before singular countable nouns that begin with a vowel sound. Refers to any member of a group.
types.rule: Use 'an' before vowel SOUNDS. Some words start with consonant letters but vowel sounds (hour, honest).

types.name: Zero Article (No Article)
types.description: Cases where no article is needed before nouns. Common with plural nouns, uncountable nouns, and proper nouns.
types.rule: No article with general plural nouns, uncountable nouns, most proper nouns, and abstract concepts.

rules.title: DO: Use 'The' with Specific Nouns
points: Use 'the' when both speaker and listener know which specific thing
Use 'the' with unique objects: the sun, the moon, the internet
Use 'the' with superlatives: the best, the tallest, the most important
Use 'the' with ordinal numbers: the first, the second, the last
Use 'the' with names of rivers, oceans, mountain ranges, deserts
examples: ‚úÖ The book you gave me is interesting. (we both know which book)
‚úÖ The sun rises in the east.
‚úÖ She is the smartest student in class.
‚úÖ This is the first time I've been here.
‚úÖ The Amazon River is the longest in South America.

rules.title: DO: Use 'A/An' with Singular Countable Nouns
points: Use 'a' or 'an' when mentioning something for the first time
Use 'a' before consonant sounds
Use 'an' before vowel sounds
Use 'a/an' with professions and occupations
Use 'a/an' in expressions of quantity: a few, a lot, a couple
examples: ‚úÖ I saw a dog in the park. (first mention)
‚úÖ It takes an hour to get there. (vowel sound)
‚úÖ He drives a European car. (consonant sound)

rules.title: DO: Omit Articles in Certain Cases
points: Don't use articles with plural nouns in general statements
Don't use articles with uncountable nouns in general
Don't use articles with most proper nouns (names, cities, countries)
Don't use articles with meals, sports, languages, subjects
Don't use articles with possessives: my book, his car

rules.title: DON'T: Mix Up 'A' and 'An'
points: Don't use 'a' before vowel sounds
Don't use 'an' before consonant sounds
Remember it's about sound, not spelling
Common mistakes: 'an university', 'a hour', 'a honest'
Silent 'h' words take 'an': hour, honor, honest
examples: ‚ùå I need a apple. ‚Üí ‚úÖ I need an apple.
‚ùå It takes a hour. ‚Üí ‚úÖ It takes an hour.
‚ùå He's an university student. ‚Üí ‚úÖ He's a university student.
‚ùå She's a honest person. ‚Üí ‚úÖ She's an honest person.
‚ùå This is an European car. ‚Üí ‚úÖ This is a European car.

rules.title: DON'T: Use 'The' with Every Noun
points: Don't use 'the' with names of people: the John (wrong)
Don't use 'the' with most countries: the France (wrong)
Don't use 'the' with general plural or uncountable nouns
Don't use 'the' with languages, sports, or meals in general
Exception: countries with 'kingdom', 'states', 'republic' take 'the'
examples: ‚ùå I met the Sarah yesterday. ‚Üí ‚úÖ I met Sarah yesterday.
‚ùå I live in the France. ‚Üí ‚úÖ I live in France.
‚ùå The dogs are animals. ‚Üí ‚úÖ Dogs are animals.
‚ùå I speak the English. ‚Üí ‚úÖ I speak English.
‚úÖ I live in the United States. (exception)

rules.title: DON'T: Forget Articles with Singular Countable Nouns
points: Singular countable nouns MUST have an article or determiner
Can't say 'I have cat' ‚Äì must be 'a cat', 'the cat', or 'my cat'
Common mistake with professions: 'She is teacher' (wrong)
Always check if singular countable noun has article
Plural and uncountable nouns can stand alone
examples: ‚ùå I have cat. ‚Üí ‚úÖ I have a cat.
‚ùå She is teacher. ‚Üí ‚úÖ She is a teacher.
‚ùå He bought car. ‚Üí ‚úÖ He bought a car.
‚ùå I need pen. ‚Üí ‚úÖ I need a pen.
‚úÖ I have cats. (plural ‚Äì OK without article)

examples.sentence: I saw a dog in the park. The dog was playing with a ball.
examples.usage_pattern: First mention uses 'a', second mention uses 'the'

examples.sentence: She is a doctor at the hospital near my house.
The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.
I need an umbrella because it's raining.
Dogs are loyal animals. The dog I have is very friendly.
She studies mathematics at the University of Oxford.

exercises.title: Fill in the Correct Articles
exercises.prompt:
Complete these sentences with 'a', 'an', 'the', or leave blank:
1. I saw ___ elephant at ___ zoo.
2. ___ water is essential for life.
3. She is ___ engineer at ___ Microsoft.
4. Can you pass me ___ salt?
5. ___ honesty is ___ best policy.
6. He plays ___ guitar very well.
7. ___ Earth revolves around ___ sun.
8. I need ___ hour to finish this.
exercises.sample_answer:
1. an elephant at the zoo
2. Water (no article)
3. an engineer at Microsoft (no article)
4. the salt
5. Honesty (no article) is the best policy
6. the guitar
7. The Earth, the sun
8. an hour

exercises.title: Identify Article Usage
exercises.passage: Yesterday, I went to a restaurant with my friends. The restaurant was near the beach. We ordered a pizza and some drinks. The pizza was delicious! After dinner, we walked along the beach and watched the sunset. It was a perfect evening. The moon was bright, and we could see the stars clearly. We took a few photos to remember the moment.
exercises.sample_answer: Articles used: a (indefinite - first mention), the (definite - specific or second mention), no article (plural/uncountable general statements)

common_mistakes.explanation: Singular countable nouns need an article. Use 'a' before professions.
Don't use 'the' with abstract nouns in general statements.

common_mistakes.correct: I need water. / I need a glass of water.
common_mistakes.explanation: 'Water' is uncountable. Don't use 'a/an' with uncountable nouns.
Don't use 'the' with most city and country names.
'Honest' starts with a vowel sound (silent h), so use 'an'.

quick_facts: 'A', 'an', and 'the' are the only articles in English.
'The' is the most commonly used word in English.
Articles don't exist in many languages, making them difficult for learners.
'A' and 'an' mean the same thing; choice depends on sound.
'The' can be used with singular, plural, or uncountable nouns.
Some words like 'university' start with vowels but use 'a' (a university).
British vs American: 'in the hospital' (US) vs 'in hospital' (UK).
